title: When writing, what is a good way to bring a dead character back to life without making it seem cheesy or cheap? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’ve read a lot of books over my lifetime, and can’t think of a single one (fiction) that ever featured the return or resurrection of a dead person that didn’t end up sounding cheesy. It’s the plot of half the soap operas, or used to be very popular. One cheap device in movies I eventually got to be fond of was the epidemic of amnesia in classic movies, especially movies from the 40’s. As a kid, I often suspected my family of having amnesia. Better to maintain quality by using a more practical reason for a person to go away for a while, and return to wherever. Since as far as I know of, there’s only one resurrection that’s widely believed in, even if not scientifically, don’t crumb up your writing with easy solutions. Good luck.

There are two ways to do this. Set your story in a world where coming back to life is normal. This works especially well if certain causes of death are necessary to properly kill people, e.g.: the beheading requirement in Highlander.Go so over the top with the cheesiness that the audience buys it. This takes more nuance than you’d think but becomes a lot of fun in a hurry. Think of movies like Scream or Drag Me to Hell.
